issue.body:
# Objective

- Fixes #15937

## Solution

- Export the variants of `Val` in the `bevy_ui` prelude.
- Updated examples to use the shortened names.

## Testing

- Ran CI.

## Notes

I'm not totally convinced this is _that_ big of a deal ergonomically. It's pretty easy for the end-user to write `use Val::{...};` at the top of their own files if it really helps them. This was a simple enough PR that I just wanted to create this as a way to decide whether #15937 should just be closed.

body: @ickshonpe has a great summary of why the free functions are better than just exporting `Val::*` here: https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/15943#pullrequestreview-2371899725
I'll note that accepting the AsValNum trait as a generic input suffers from the same problem that the extension method suffers from (not playing well with function reflection).

What about a macro based syntax described in #20366? I think that would have the benefit of allowing more freedom and being easier to understand (especially with prior knowledge of CSS). This would also have the advantage of not having to write out percent, which would have similar problems as the current approach.

If #20366 isn't well received, I'd be willing to finally implement this so we'd finally have a solution to this problem.

issue.body:
## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill?

It is quite cumbersome to always have to write `Val::Px(40.0)` or `Val::Percent(100.0)`. This clutters the code and adds some boilerplate that makes it less readable, especially when doing a lot of UI stuff in one place. You always have to scan for `Val::` and then look at the type before looking at the value. This flow could be improved.

Also, a lot of times, you don't need the decimal point so this just adds to the boilerplate clutter.

## What solution would you like?

Add a macro that translates CSS-like unit notation to the `Val` type.

My first proposal would be the following syntax:

```rs
val!(40px)  // Val::Px(40.0)
val!(0)     // Val::Px(0.0) although this is debatable
val!(auto)  // Val::Auto
val!(70.4%) // Val::Percent(70.4)
```

## What alternative(s) have you considered?

Adding helper functions as described in #15937. But this would have the downside of not having access to any characters such as `%`. Also, the syntax proposed here has the upside of being similar to the CSS syntax, making it easier to learn and understand.

## Additional context

I would be willing to implement this, but first I would like some feedback on the syntax and suggestions for additional features. Should the compiler/macro perform some checks for some of the values? I can't think of any, but maybe I'm missing something.

Please give your opinion on this and if there is a general consensus that we should add something like this, I will implement it.

body:
Copying my comment from the linked issue:

> I am strongly opposed to adding macros to improve this. My preferred solution is to use BSN's automatic `Into` calls and exporting Val variants in the bevy_ui prelude to resolve this, as discussed with @cart previously on Discord.

I think that `impl From<f32> for `Val`` and `impl From<i32> for Val` would do wonders to improve this.

But what unit would that then be converted to? Pixels by default? Or is there some kind of misunderstanding?

Because I dont think setting a default unit is a good idea. It would complicate things for beginners especially due to the lack of missing documentation where such a thing could be documented. I did like the idea of helper functions that take something like `impl AsValNum`. (Or something similar, as long as the unit is explicit)

Please tell me if Im overthinking anything.

Also, could you link to the discord discussion that you mentioned?

I see your point about the challenges around default units. The helper functions are a sensible idea. Looking for message sources: I found [this message](https://discord.com/channels/691052431525675048/1264881140007702558/1374051004638564422).

> @CooCooCaCha:  Something Ive wondered about is allowing users to register helper functions with the BSN system and using them in BSN files.
>
> Adding full expression support seems like a rabbit hole and a non-starter since thats basically a mini bevy scripting language. 
>
> But just helper functions would be useful and potentially allow a lot of functionality. Like letting people create their own expression language and passing it to the registered helper function. 


> @cart:  yup this is already the plan (specifically, things like px(10) returning Val::Px(10))

I may have misremembered!
